title: Christians apology to gays and lesbians
text:

Picture: Craig Wilson Christians offer national apology to gay and lesbian community Martin Newman, The Daily Telegraph February 23, 2017 6:22pm 
AN Australian Christian group has offered an apology to the LGBTIQ community for ‘discrimination and hurt’ caused by the church and plans a national reconciliation process. 
Former NSW Premier Kristina Keneally is one of the supporters of Equal Voices, a non-denominational organisation, which said it would present the document to parliament. 
A rally on the steps of St James Anglican Church in King Street, Sydney, tomorrow night will encourage Christians from all groups to sign the apology. 
Rev. Dr. Keith Mascord, a founding member of Equal Voices, said: “The National Apology will recognise the discrimination and hurt caused by Christian behaviour and attitudes, particularly in regard to ‘conversion therapy’ and “pray away the gay” movements. 
“The purpose of the National Apology is to begin a reconciliation process between Australian Christians and LGBTIQ+ fellow Australians. 
“We invite Christians of all denominations to join us in reflection and apology at St James Church in Sydney.” media_camera Sydney’s Gay Mardi Gras season runs until March 5 
The move comes in the midst of Sydney’s Gay Mardi Gras season, with events taking place up until March 5. 
This week many councils around Sydney, including Woollahra and Randwick, have raised the rainbow flag of the gay and lesbian community in support. 
Rev. Mascord added the apology will eventually be presented to Parliament on behalf of those who have signed it. 
“As Christians, we must be the first to reach out our hands in apology to those who are LGBTIQ+ and affirm their place in church and society. 
“We encourage all Christians to read and hopefully join the apology and to join us this evening, witness this intentional step towards reconciliation and respect.” 
Equal Voices started as a grassroots multi-denominational organisation comprised of Christians from around Australia. It has found some prominent supporters including Keneally and former top judge Michael Kirby AC 
The National Apology will launch at St James Anglican Church, 171 King Street, Sydney at 6.30pm, Friday 24 February. A Q&A session will follow from 7.30pm in the nearby St James Hall.
